qas.question: From where is the sovereign typically forbidden?
Whose job is it to release parliament after the ceremony?

answers.text: The governor general or his or her deputy

qas.question: Who reads the formal statement after the list of bills has been finished?
Which position nods their head to signify assention?
What ceremony takes place in the House?
On the day of the event, the President of the Senate reads to whom?
On the day of the event, the President of the Senate reads what?
Who follows Black Rod back to the Senate?

context: <b4_0>The Royal Assent<b4_0/> ceremony takes place in the Senate, as the sovereign is traditionally barred from the <a0_0>House of Commons<a0_0/>. On the day of the event, the Speaker of the Senate will read to the <b5_0>chamber<b5_0/> <b6_0>a notice from the secretary<b6_0/> to the governor general indicating when the viceroy or a deputy thereof will arrive. The Senate thereafter cannot adjourn until after the ceremony. The speaker moves to sit beside the throne, the Mace Bearer, with mace in hand, stands adjacent to him or her, and the governor general enters to take the speaker's chair. The Usher of the Black Rod is then commanded by the speaker to summon the <b7_0>Members of Parliament<b7_0/>, who follow Black Rod back to the Senate, the Sergeant-at-Arms carrying the mace of the House of Commons. In the Senate, those from the commons stand behind the bar, while Black Rod proceeds to stand next to the governor general, who then nods his or her head to signify Royal Assent to the presented bills (which do not include appropriations bills). Once the list of bills is complete, the <a2_0>Clerk of the Senate<a2_0/> states: "in Her Majesty's name, His [or Her] Excellency the Governor General [or the deputy] doth assent to these bills." If there are any appropriation bills to receive Royal Assent, the Speaker of the House of Commons will read their titles and the Senate clerk repeats them to the <a3_0>governor general<a3_0/>, who nods his or her head to communicate Royal Assent. When these bills have all been assented to, the Clerk of the Senate recites "in Her Majesty's name, His [or Her] Excellency the Governor General [or the deputy] thanks her loyal subjects, accepts their benevolence and assents to these bills. <a1_0>The governor general or his or her deputy<a1_0/> then depart parliament.
